critique: This document primarily concerns the delegation of authority related to foreign assistance programs. It amends a previous executive order (EO 12163) to reflect changes in legislation (Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1988). It's largely administrative, assigning responsibilities to the Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, and the Director of the International Development Cooperation Agency. There's little to suggest a strong ideological tilt, immigration stance, or impact on civil liberties. The changes seem to maintain existing structures rather than drastically altering them. The document does delegate presidential power to other members of the executive branch. It is difficult to assess the economic regulation or social inclusion implications of this document.
